concepts.title: Five-Kingdom Classification
concepts.content: Robert Whittaker (1969) classified living organisms into Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae and Animalia using criteria such as cell type, body organization and mode of nutrition.
concepts.funFact: Earlier systems had only two kingdoms: plants and animals.

concepts.title: Major Groups of Microbes
concepts.content: Microbes include bacteria, protozoa, fungi, algae and viruses. Many are useful (curd formation, decomposition), while some cause diseases.

examples.text: Virus can cause flu and polio.

keyPoints.text: Viruses are acellular and need host cells.
Some microbes are beneficial in nutrient recycling.

concepts.funFact: One gram of healthy soil may contain millions of microorganisms.

concepts.title: Useful and Harmful Microbes
concepts.content: Microbes have both advantages and disadvantages. They are used in food industry, medicine and environment, but can also cause infections in plants, animals and humans.

examples.text: Antibiotics are produced by some fungi and bacteria.
Rhizobium fixes nitrogen in legume roots.
Pathogenic microbes can cause cholera, malaria, or rust disease in crops.

keyPoints.text: Vaccination protects against many viral diseases.

concepts.funFact: Penicillin, the first antibiotic, was discovered from a fungus.
